In my [previous post](/posts/first-post/index.qmd) I mentioned my interest in constructive QFT, gauge Theory and HoTT. I‚Äôll try to explain ‚Äúhow did you even get here dawgü•Ä?!?‚Äù and why I‚Äôm interested in them :3

When I studied logic the first time I was really fascinated by predicate logic and formal proofs OwO. In fact, I really enjoyed solving proof problems because it followed more logically than cookie-cutter ‚Äúfind the missing trick‚Äù problem. I had a fascination with abstract concepts from high school at age 15.

This fascination always led me towards more abstract ideas and mathematics and along with my interest in physics Through some Wikipedia reading and chaotic explorations on the internet, I found that standard perturbative-QFT although makes predictions of scattering amplitudes extremely accurately, as a formal framework it is a bit ‚Äúshaky‚Äù.

Path integrals are not well-defined measures, as it lacks rigorous sigma-algebra and has UV-divergences. Renormalisation isn‚Äôt rigorously well understood and through RG flows QFT is better treated as an effective field theory (frankly, I think it‚Äôs just a trick which physicists use to sweep infinities under the rug and call it a day, but this is just my penguin brain speaking, womp womp :3).

Understanding why the methods of QFT work is extremely important for QFT in curved space, and to avoid using the rules in wrong situations and get fake solutions, especially in non-perturbative regimes.

This led me to discover 70-80s work of Glimm-Jaffe on constructive quantum field theory which aimed to formally justify the heuristics physicists use. They were successful in proving a mass gap in Quantum Yang-Mills Theory in two and three dimensions but hit a wall in four dimensions, which is a Millennium prize problem and extremely difficult.

In the modern era, this problem is often approached from a stochastic perspective by using Langevin dynamics in SPDEs. Martin Hairer made a breakthrough with regularity structures for singular SPDEs, for this he won many awards including the Fields medal. However, the 4D Yang-Mills still remains an open problem because of how extremely difficult it is.

I've explained about QFT with more technical details [here](/research.qmd).

The necessary background needed (as far as im aware) is rigorous understanding of functional analysis, operator algebras, distribution theory, and measure theory. Currently my background is only basic understanding of analysis and algebra so I‚Äôm quite far from understanding the mathematics, but I‚Äôm making progress day by day at my pace.

This problem is one of the hardest in mathematical physics and people are generally cautious of young students chasing the big problems just because of the glamour.
